title: 105_hr2135
content:
The "International Tobacco Responsibility Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title. It addresses exports and advertising of tobacco products abroad. Labeling Requirements for Exports state that it is illegal to export cigarettes without the required label statements in the primary language of the destination country. The Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986 prohibits the export of smokeless tobacco products without the required label statements in the primary language of the destination country. The President can waive this prohibition if the destination country has similar or stricter labeling requirements. The President can grant waivers for stricter labeling requirements under the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act and the Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986. It is unlawful to advertise cigarettes or smokeless tobacco abroad without the required label statements in the same language as the advertising message. It is illegal to advertise smokeless tobacco products abroad without the necessary label statements, as required by the Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986. The President has the authority to grant waivers for countries with similar or stricter advertising requirements for cigarettes or smokeless tobacco products. The President can grant waivers for countries with advertising requirements similar to or stricter than those in the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act or the Comprehensive Smokeless Tobacco Health Education Act of 1986. Waivers granted will be published in the Federal Register. SEC. 3. PENALTIES.

(a) Fine.--Violators of section 2 may be fined up to $100,000.
(b) Injunction Proceedings.--District courts can prevent violations of section 2 upon the Attorney General's request.

SEC. 4. REPEAL.

Section 12 of the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is repealed.

SEC. 5. RESTRICTIONS ON ACTIVITIES ABROAD REGARDING THE MARKETING OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS. Prohibition on using funds to seek removal of restrictions on tobacco products in foreign countries or promote their export or sale abroad. Export promotion activities under this section include activities to help US businesses market cigarettes, little cigars, snuff, chewing tobacco, or smokeless tobacco abroad competitively with businesses from other countries. This includes trade development, dissemination of foreign marketing opportunities, development of economic policies, and exhibition of products in other countries. The Section 301 Committee assisting the US Trade Representative must include representatives from the Department of Health and Human Services for cases involving tobacco products. Congress suggests the President urge the UN to create a conference on global tobacco use regulation. The President has the authority to issue regulations to implement this Act. The Act defines key terms such as "cigarette", "foreign subsidiary", and "smokeless tobacco". The Act defines "smokeless tobacco" as finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf tobacco intended for oral placement.
